text:
HOMEOWNER’S GUIDE TO
BUILDING AND RENOVATING
USEFUL INFORMATION TO HELP YOU THROUGH
THE BUILDING AND RENOVATING PROCESS.
SEPTEMBER 2024

WELCOME
Building and Renovating
When you first start thinking about building a new house or renovating, it can
be overwhelming. Having a clear plan and understanding the different roles and
responsibilities of all the key players can mean the difference between a good
experience and a disappointing one.
In this homeowner ’s guide, find out how to begin your project, from choosing
a builder, getting quotes and plans, to considering whether you want to do the
work yourself. Learn about supervision and the responsibilities of the builder or
construction manager. You ’ll also find out what certifiers do and their role in the
building inspection and approval process.
Taking out insurance may not be a high priority right now but is an important
part of the process. Our guide will help you understand insurance cover and
the policies that you will need.
ABOUT US
The QBCC supports the growing Queensland community by providing information,
advice and regulation to ensure the maintenance of proper building standards and
remedies for defective building work. Led by the Commissioner and governed by
a board, the QBCC consists of a skilled and expert team of staff that work hard to
meet the needs of industry participants and the community.
The Commission regulates the building industry throughout Queensland.
To provide the best customer service possible, service centres are located throughout
the state including Brisbane, Gold Coast, Sunshine Coast, Toowoomba, Maryborough,
Rockhampton, Mackay, Townsville and Cairns.
With over 4.6 million people currently living in Queensland and a robust percentage
of those residents working in the construction sector, the QBCC has an important task
in serving our customers, contributing to the growth of the Queensland economy and
regulating the industry.
If you ’d like to learn more, visit qbcc.qld.gov.au.
QBCC HOMEOWNER ’S GUIDE / BUILDING AND RENOVATION | 3

WHAT DOES THE QBCC DO?

with us for further advice.
NOTE: Time limits apply for the lodgement of disputes
with the QBCC.
4 | QBCC HOMEOWNER’S GUIDE / BUILDING AND RENOVATION

The six QBCC contracts which relate to domestic
building work are:
1. QBCC New Home Construction Contract - for the
construction of an entire home;
2. QBCC Level 1 Renovation, Extension and Repair Contract
-for renovations, extensions and routine repairs on existing
homes, and associated domestic building work, priced at
$3,301 to $19,999;
3. QBCC Level 2 Renovation, Extension and Repair Contract
-for renovations, associated domestic building work and
routine repairs on existing homes, priced at $20,000 or
more;
4. QBCC Natural Disaster Repairs Contract - for repairs to a
home, duplex or home unit of any value arising from damage
caused by a natural disaster;
5. Small Building Projects Contract - for domestic building
projects not exceeding $3,300; and
6. QBCC Contract for Demolition of Residential Premises -
for demolition work of any value associated with domestic
building projects.
All of these contracts are available for download free of charge
from our website at qbcc.qld.gov.au
Just about any work you have done on or around your
home should be undertaken by QBCC- licensed contractors
(builders, trade contractors and building designers).
On our YouTube channel you’ll find many resources to help guide
you through the building process. You can subscribe to our
channel and choose to be notified by email whenever we upload a
new video. This is a great way to keep your knowledge up-to-date
if you’re planning to build, extend or renovate.
QBCC HOMEOWNER’S GUIDE / BUILDING AND RENOVATION | 5

COMMUNICATION GETTING STARTED
Good communication between you and your contractor Finance

Maintain good, regular communication with your builder • shop around and compare quotes

SUSTAINABLE DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS
If your project involves major renovation or extension of an You should carefully consider these matters and discuss

These choices will ultimately enhance your comfort and

can considerably reduce the cost of maintaining your
regard to sustainability and mobility considerations are

accurately incorporated and fully detailed in the contract
these matters may also improve your home’s efficiency

and increase its future resale value. Where relevant to
your renovation project, it is also recommended that your Further information on sustainable design for domestic
design considerations include an allowance for any mobility building projects is available from the following websites;
difficulties you, your relatives or visitors have now or may -qld.gov.au/housing/building-home/sustainable-housing
have in the foreseeable future (relevant considerations -energyrating.gov.au
might include eliminating the use of steps, increasing the
width of doorways and corridors, allowing for wheelchair
access to bathrooms and toilets, installing switches,
handrails and framing elements in walls for future
handrails at appropriate heights and locations,
etc. Refer to Liveable Housing Design 2022 for
more information.
When addressing these design considerations,
the objective is to avoid or minimise the need for
expensive home modifications, or in the worst
case to have to sell your home, in the event you
or someone in your family experiences a change
in their mobility through injury, illness or age.
It is important to ensure you comply with the
National Construction Code and any local
planning requirements. Contact your local
authority for more information.
It is generally much cheaper to address these
sustainability considerations at planning
stage, and incorporate them at the point of
construction or renovation than it is to retrofit
them or modify your home after the event.
QBCC HOMEOWNER’S GUIDE / BUILDING AND RENOVATION | 7

NON
CONFORMING
BUILDING
PRODUCTS
NOTE
Persons in the chain of
responsibility
for an NCBP are obligated by law to
notify the QBCC if they suspect or know
The use of non-conforming building products in the buildings their product has caused, or exposed
in which we work, live and play, puts lives and property at risk. persons to the risk of, death, serious
Laws are in place that declare all parties involved in the building
product supply chain, from the manufacturers and importers
injury or illness.
to the suppliers and installers, and sometimes architects and
engineers, are held accountable for building products that are
not compliant or safe for their intended use.
Information about the building product and its intended use
must be provided by each person in the supply chain to the
next person in the chain. What should I do if I suspect a NCBP?
If you are concerned that a NCBP has been used in your home,
What is a non-conforming building
you should raise this with the tradesperson who installed
product (NCBP)?
it. Ask them for the information showing that the building
product meets the required standards. If they don’t provide
The law states that a building product is regarded as non-
this information, contact the QBCC.
conforming if it is unsafe, does not comply with the relevant
regulatory provisions (e.g. the National Construction Code),
Where can I go for help or more information?
or its performance does not meet or is incapable of meeting
the claimed standard or performance.
More information on NCBPs, including on how to complain about
A building product is also regarded as non-conforming if it a suspected NCBP, can be obtained from qbcc.qld.gov.au.
claims to be something it is not and is marketed and supplied
with the intent to deceive consumers.
What does this mean for homeowners?
Fixings
The laws aim to eliminate the use of NCBPs by imposing Roofng
responsibilities on those involved at the earliest stages of a
typical building supply chain. They will help provide greater
safety and certainty for homeowners and save money by
preventing costly rectification works.
How can I minimise the risk of NCBPs
in my home?
There are many steps that you can take to reduce
Ceilings
the likelihood of NCBPs being installed in your home.
Choosing a tradesperson – Choosing a licensed
Structural frames
tradesperson will ensure they are properly qualified
and insured. They also have a legal requirement to
use only building products that comply with the
Window frames
standards under the National Construction Code.
Choosing the right building products for the job –
The law requires that building products are
accompanied by information that allows you to
determine whether the product is fit for its
Glass
intended use. If you are purchasing building Flooring
products make sure you check the information
with a licensed tradesperson. If your builder is
supplying the product, check with them that the Glass
product meets the required standards. Glass Locks Window
Handles frames
Plumbing products - Check that plumbing products
have the relevant WaterMark certification.
Doors

CHOOSING YOUR BUILDER
CHECK THE LICENCE CARD!
Obtaining plans and quotes
The first step is to make a list of local builders willing and able
to do the job, then check their qualifications and past work.
You can find builders and trade contractors through:
• personal recommendations from friends, family or
neighbours who have built/renovated recently
• industry associations (e.g. MBAQ, HIA, etc.)
• advertisements in the local media
• on-site signs
• trade directories
• the QBCC Online Licence Search.
* This Licence Card is current as at August 2024
As the basis for the building work to be done, the plans and
specifications form an integral part of the agreement between
you and your building contractor. Check them carefully for
accuracy and completeness before signing a building contract!
The licence card includes name of the licensee,
For the purposes of comparison, you should try to obtain several licence number, type of work covered and expiry date*.
written quotes based on the completed plans and specifications.
Note: These quotes are not proper building contracts, just an
indication of price.
• Did the contractor stick to the agreed costs and timing?
Remember: the cheapest quote is not always the best.
• Did the contractor properly document and obtain prior
Explain clearly to your building contractor, from quote stage, the
approval in writing for any variations?
full details of work you require. Always try to obtain a fixed price
for all or most of the work.

DOMESTIC BUILDING CONTRACT LEGISLATION
(SCHEDULE 1B OF THE QBCC ACT)
NOTE
GET IT IN WRITING!
All domestic building work priced at
over $3,300 must be covered by a written
contract which complies with Schedule 1B of
the QBCC Act.
Homeowners should carefully
check their contract
documentation and, if
necessary, seek formal legal advice before
signing to ensure it complies with the Act.
Domestic building legislation (now Schedule 1B of the QBCC Act) You may NOT withdraw during the cooling off period if:

to Queensland homeowners undertaking domestic building work • you and your contractor had a previous contract on similar

The ‘cooling off’ period
Plans and specifications
All contracts for domestic building work priced at over
$3,300 must include advice to homeowners of their right to If your project requires building approval, you’ll need plans and
a “cooling off” period. Under the QBCC Act, homeowners may specifications that must be included in the contract. They may
withdraw from the contract during the cooling off period, usually be prepared by the building contractor or drawn up for you by
within 5 business days after receiving from the contractor a copy an independent architect, engineer or building designer.
of the entire signed contract (if the contract price is $20,000 or
more) and a copy of the QBCC Consumer Building Guide.
If a homeowner wishes to withdraw they must give a signed notice
of their intention to withdraw under the cooling off provisions
in s35 of Schedule 1B to the contractor and pay certain costs
(usually $100 plus ‘out-of-pocket expenses reasonably incurred
by the contractor before the building owner withdrew from the
contract’).

DURING CONSTRUCTION
Workplace health and safety NOTE
The contractor acts as “principal contractor” for the purposes While the builder has a statutory obligation
of the requirements of the Work Health and Safety Act 2011 to notify the certifier at certain construction
for the duration of the contract. stages, homeowners are ultimately responsible
The contractor must ensure all persons at the site comply with for ensuring that approvals are granted and the
all applicable requirements pursuant to the Work Health and required inspections are carried out.
Safety Act 2011 and may exclude or remove from the site any
person who fails to comply. (Arrangements for building certification
and inspection should, therefore, be discussed
and agreed with the builder and recorded in
the contract).

Building approvals and inspections make the final contract payment.
This section aims to answer common questions about the
building approval and inspection process in Queensland.
Who can provide building approvals and inspections? What is the building certifier’s role?
Approvals for building work must be obtained from a building Often, the contractor will engage the building certifier on behalf
certifier (either a private certifier or a building certifier employed of the homeowner. If, however, you wish to engage the building
by a local authority). The approvals generally state the mandatory certifier you should check the certifier’s licence details and history
stages of building work to be inspected. The certifier must be with the QBCC. You may wish to contact the certifier to discuss
notified when a ‘stage of building work’ is ready for inspection. the certification process. Under the Building Act 1975, the certifier
The inspection must be carried out by a building certifier; or in engagement must be in writing and must state the fees payable.
some instances the building certifier may authorise a competent
There are matters over which building certifiers have no
person to undertake the inspection.
digression, and which can only be decided by the local
The building approval documents will outline mandatory government. These matters include the relaxation of the
inspections required by the certifier for the build. boundary set-back requirements applying to dwellings, patios,
and domestic outbuildings; and disability exemptions for the
installation of swimming pool fences. While the certifier may assist
in making an application to local government, the owner may
wish to contact the local government to discuss the process for
these types of applications.
NOTE
What is the purpose and timing of building inspections?
I c t e i r s t u if n y l a o w r a fu p l p f r o o r v a e b w u o il r d k i n w g i t c h e w rt h if i i c e h r t t o h ey T c ‘G e h u r e t i d i p f e i r e l i i r m n i e s a r t f y o o r f e u i n n n s s c u p t r e i e o c n t t h io o a f n t o o a n s f - p c s e l i a t c e s t s s b 1 u o a i f l n d c d i o n n 1 g 0 s i t n b ru s u p c il e t d i c o in t n i g o u s n ’ n s c d o b e m y r a t p h l b y e u w ild it i h n g th e
are personally involved as a builder or building approval, and relevant codes [including the Building Code
designer, or from which they are able to of Australia (BCA)]. Building certifiers are required to act in the
public interest. It is not the role of the certifier to ensure compliance
derive a profit.
with the terms of the contract or to assess the quality of the work or
to perform ongoing supervision on behalf the owner.
Mandatory stages of building work to be inspected are defined
under s.44 of the Building Regulation. More generally, for
dwellings the stages may include footing, slab, frame, final
and any other stage identified on the building approval.

Under the relevant Queensland legislation, building inspections BUILDING DISPUTES

footing, slab, frame and final.

When QBCC can’t help
• when the value of the building work is less than $3,300,
including labour, materials and GST - excluding plumbing,
drainage, gas fitting, chemical termite management
system installation, building design, site classification, fire
protection and completed building inspections, which
can be investigated regardless of the value and hydraulic
design work valued over $1,100
• when your complaint is lodged outside the statutory
timeframes (refer to Complaints and disputes – Help with
defective work)
• when complaints are solely about electrical work
(contact the Electrical Safety Office)
• when you can’t identify the contractor responsible for the work
• complaints about dividing fences (except if the work
is defective)
• when the complaint is about contract conditions and
payment disputes (refer to Complaints and disputes – QCAT ).
Dispute resolution
When negotiations between you and your builder or trade
contractor break down, and rectification work is not completed,
there are options and procedures for resolving your dispute.
What can the QBCC do for you?
QBCC provides an equitable and effective dispute resolution
service for disputes between QBCC licensees and homeowners
concerning building defects.
Your first step is to convey your concerns in writing to your building
contractor. Give your contractor written notice of every defective
or unfinished item (e.g. by email or letter). The notice must give
a timeframe (e.g. 14 days) for the contractor to rectify the items
(not required if they are bankrupt or insolvent and have had their
licence cancelled, deregistered or deceased). You can search
QBCC’s licence register to check the status of their licence.
Make sure you date, sign and keep a copy of the letter for
your records.
QBCC HOMEOWNER’S GUIDE / BUILDING AND RENOVATION | 19

If you still can’t resolve the problems in a reasonable time,
call the QBCC to discuss the matter. To access the QBCC dispute
THINKING OF OWNER BUILDING?
resolution service you will have to complete a Residential and
Commercial Construction Work Complaint Form (available on the
QBCC website or from any QBCC office) and provide a copy of
your letter to the contractor and other relevant documents.
A QBCC Resolution Services Officer will assess your submission
and contact you and the contractor to try to facilitate an
agreement. Only if this is unsuccessful and if defective work
is alleged, we may inspect to decide if the work is defective
or not. If we find the work is defective, we can issue a formal
notice (called a Direction to Rectify) to the contractor giving
them 35 days to fix the work. If the contractor is required to
rectify defects you must allow them reasonable access to the site.
The QBCC considers reasonable access to be:
• a time agreed to by you and the contractor
• during normal working hours
• for full consecutive days if required
• providing a minimum of 48 hours’ notice has been given
by the contractor.
Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal (QCAT)
QCAT provides cost-effective dispute resolution, particularly
for building disputes of a contractual nature. QCAT do however
Under the Queensland Building and Construction Commission
require you to first apply to resolve your dispute through
Act 1991 (QBCC Act), if you wish to complete or coordinate
the QBCC before they will accept an application to decide
building work on your own property valued at $11,000 or
a building dispute.
more, you must obtain an owner builder permit. The value of
At the end of the QBCC’s dispute resolution process we will the building work includes labour (i.e. the cost if a licensed
issue you a letter so you can apply to QCAT if you’d like their help. builder performed the work), materials and GST.
For more information on owner-building, visit our website
More information on the Tribunal’s procedures can be obtained
qbcc.qld.gov.au
by calling 1300 753 228, or visiting their website qcat.qld.gov.au
Other options
WARNING
There may be other remedies available to you under the contract,
including liquidated damages (where you receive a pre-arranged
amount of money per day if the builder fails to complete the There is NO Queensland Home Warranty
project on time), or, in certain circumstances (e.g. major blowouts Protection for Owner Builders!
in costs or construction time), termination of the contract.
Action in the court system may also be available.

QUEENSLAND HOME WARRANTY SCHEME
Make sure you’re covered
The Queensland Home Warranty Scheme provides consumers NOTE
with the most comprehensive home warranty protection available.
Cover commences from either the date of payment of the The Queensland Home Warranty Scheme
premium, the date of signing a contract or when the building provides substantial cover against
contractor commences the work (whichever is the earliest). non-completion, defects and subsidence
for up to 6 years and 6 months
What is covered?

work called residential construction work. Residential construction
work is building work over $3,300 in value carried out by a

Construction management contracts

A construction management contract is not covered for

NOTES
otherwise met the terms of cover, could be the subject of
a non-completion claim in the event the trade contractor
failed to complete the work.
Rectification of defective work prior to lodging claim
The terms of cover provide that a consumer is not entitled
to compensation where a consumer rectifies or completes
the work without QBCC’s prior approval. This is because
the QBCC is unable to verify the validity of the claim, or
quantify it.
Under the terms of cover, the QBCC must decline the claim
where a consumer rectifies or completes the work without
QBCC’s prior approval.
